meaning: The smallest part of an element that can exist.
Positively charged subatomic particle with a relative mass of 1
Subatomic particle without charge with a relative mass of 1
Negatively charged subatomic particle, with a very small relative mass
The positively charged centre of an atom, made from protons and neutrons.
The number of protons (or electrons) in an atom.
A charged atom; an atom that has lost or gained one or more electrons.
Particles of the same element, but with different numbers of neutrons.
The elements in Group 1 of the periodic table
A column on the periodic table.
A row on the periodic table.
A table of elements arranged in order of atomic number, initially created by Mendeleev.
A substance made up of two or more atoms that are chemically bonded.
A method of separation that is used to separate a mixture of chemicals by distributing the components between two phases.
A method of separation involving the production of solid crystals from a solution through evaporation.
A method of separation that separates solids from liquids
A method of separation used to separate a mixture of substances with different boiling points.
A reaction where a more reactive element displaces a less reactive element from a compound.
A substance made from a single type of atom.
The elements in Group 7 of the periodic table
An element that forms positive ions by delocalising electrons
A substance made from one or more types of element or compound, not chemically bonded.
The elements in Group 0 of the periodic table.
A model of the atom with most mass concentrated in the centre, in the positively charged nucleus, and with electrons orbiting in shells.
A model of the atom, where electrons are dotted randomly throughout a ball of positive charge.
The average mass (relative to a proton/neutron) of an element weighted by each isotope's abundance.
A value calculated by the combined number of protons and neutrons
Different layers where electrons are located in around an atom.
The man who invented the modern periodic table, with spaces missing that would later be filled, grouped based on properties
The discoverer of the electron, and creator of the plum pudding model
The main man associated with the alpha scattering experiment and hence, forming the nuclear model
The creator of an early periodic table, organised to groups of 8. However, he placed elements in an arrangement that their properties did not fit
The discoverer of electron shells/energy levels
Discoverer of the neutron
Metals found between Groups 2 and 3 in the periodic table.
